text: MARX AND SOCIALIST DOCTRINE
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: SOCIALISM, like everything else that is vital, is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rather a tendency than a strictly definable body of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doctrine. A definition of Socialism is sure either to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: include some views which many would regard as not
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socialistic, or to exclude others which claim to be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: included. But I think we shall come nearest to the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: essence of Socialism by defining it as the advocacy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of communal ownership of land and capital. Communal
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ownership may mean ownership by a democratic
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: State, but cannot be held to include ownership
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by any State which is not democratic. Communal
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ownership may also be understood, as Anarchist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Communism understands it, in the sense of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ownership by the free association of the men and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: women in a community without those compulsory
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: powers which are necessary to constitute a State.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Some Socialists expect communal ownership to arrive
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: suddenly and completely by a catastrophic revolution,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: while others expect it to come gradually, first
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in one industry, then in another. Some insist upon
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the necessity of completeness in the acquisition of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: land and capital by the public, while others would
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be content to see lingering islands of private ownership,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: provided they were not too extensive or powerful.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: What all forms have in common is democracy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and the abolition, virtual or complete, of the present
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capitalistic system. The distinction between Socialists,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: affairs of the community. But all alike are
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Two questions are raised by Marx's work: First,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Are his laws of historical development true? Second,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Is Socialism desirable? The second of these questions
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is quite independent of the first. Marx professes
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to prove that Socialism must come, but scarcely concerns
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: himself to argue that when it comes it will be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a good thing. It may be, however, that if it comes,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it will be a good thing, even though all Marx's arguments
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to prove that it must come should be at fault.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In actual fact, time has shown many flaws in Marx's
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: theories. The development of the world has been
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sufficiently like his prophecy to prove him a man of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: very unusual penetration, but has not been sufficiently
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: like to make either political or economic history
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exactly such as he predicted that it would be.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Nationalism, so far from diminishing, has increased,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and has failed to be conquered by the cosmopolitan
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tendencies which Marx rightly discerned in finance.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Although big businesses have grown bigger and have
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: over a great area reached the stage of monopoly,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: yet the number of shareholders in such enterprises
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is so large that the actual number of individuals
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: interested in the capitalist system has continually
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: increased. Moreover, though large firms have grown
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: larger, there has been a simultaneous increase in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: firms of medium size. Meanwhile the wage-earners,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who were, according to Marx, to have remained at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the bare level of subsistence at which they were in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the England of the first half of the nineteenth century,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have instead profited by the general increase
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of wealth, though in a lesser degree than the capitalists.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The supposed iron law of wages has been
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proved untrue, so far as labor in civilized countries
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is concerned. If we wish now to find examples of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capitalist cruelty analogous to those with which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of our material to the Tropics, or at any rate to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regions where there are men of inferior races to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exploit. Again: the skilled worker of the present day
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is an aristocrat in the world of labor. It is a question
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with him whether he shall ally himself with the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unskilled worker against the capitalist, or with the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capitalist against the unskilled worker. Very often
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he is himself a capitalist in a small way, and if he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is not so individually, his trade union or his friendly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: society is pretty sure to be so. Hence the sharpness
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the class war has not been maintained. There
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are gradations, intermediate ranks between rich and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: poor, instead of the clear-cut logical antithesis
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between the workers who have nothing and the capitalists
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who have all. Even in Germany, which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a powerful Social-Democratic party, nominally
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: accepting the doctrine of ``Das Kapital'' as all but
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: verbally inspired, even there the enormous increase
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of wealth in all classes in the years preceding the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: war led Socialists to revise their beliefs and to adopt
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an evolutionary rather than a revolutionary attitude.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Bernstein, a German Socialist who lived long in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: England, inaugurated the ``Revisionist'' movement
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which at last conquered the bulk of the party. His
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: criticisms of Marxian orthodoxy are set forth in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his ``Evolutionary Socialism.''[9] Bernstein's work,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as is common in Broad Church writers, consists
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: largely in showing that the Founders did not hold
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: their doctrines so rigidly as their followers have
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: done. There is much in the writings of Marx and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Engels that cannot be fitted into the rigid orthodoxy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which grew up among their disciples. Bernstein's
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: main criticisms of these disciples, apart from such as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: we have already mentioned, consist in a defense of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: piecemeal action as against revolution. He protests
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: against the attitude of undue hostility to Liberalism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is common among Socialists, and he blunts the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: edge of the Internationalism which undoubtedly is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: part of the teachings of Marx. The workers, he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: says, have a Fatherland as soon as they become
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: citizens, and on this basis he defends that degree of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nationalism which the war has since shown to be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prevalent in the ranks of Socialists. He even goes
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so far as to maintain that European nations have a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: right to tropical territory owing to their higher
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: civilization. Such doctrines diminish revolutionary
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wing of the Liberal Party. But the increasing prosperity
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of wage-earners before the war made these
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: developments inevitable. Whether the war will have
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: altered conditions in this respect, it is as yet
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: impossible to know. Bernstein concludes with the wise
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: remark that: ``We have to take working men as they
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are. And they are neither so universally paupers as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was set out in the Communist Manifesto, nor so free
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from prejudices and weaknesses as their courtiers
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wish to make us believe.''
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [9] Die Voraussetzungen des Sozialismus und die Aufgaben
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

text: der Sozial-Demokratie.''
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

text: In March, 1914, Bernstein delivered a lecture in Budapest
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in which he withdrew from several of the positions he had taken
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: up (vide Budapest ``Volkstimme,'' March 19, 1914).
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

text: Berstein represents the decay of Marxian orthodoxy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from within. Syndicalism represents an attack
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: against it from without, from the standpoint of a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doctrine which professes to be even more radical and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: more revolutionary than that of Marx and Engels.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The attitude of Syndicalists to Marx may be seen in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Sorel's little book, ``La Decomposition du Marxisme,''
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and in his larger work, ``Reflections on
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Violence,'' authorized translation by T. E. Hulme
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: (Allen & Unwin, 1915). After quoting Bernstein,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with approval in so far as he criticises Marx, Sorel
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proceeds to other criticisms of a different order. He
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: points out (what is true) that Marx's theoretical
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: economics remain very near to Manchesterism: the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: orthodox political economy of his youth was accepted
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by him on many points on which it is now known to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be wrong. According to Sorel, the really essential
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: thing in Marx's teaching is the class war. Whoever
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: keeps this alive is keeping alive the spirit of Socialism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: much more truly than those who adhere to the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: letter of Social-Democratic orthodoxy. On the basis
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the class war, French Syndicalists developed a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: criticism of Marx which goes much deeper than those
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that we have been hitherto considering. Marx's
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: views on historical development may have been in a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: greater or less degree mistaken in fact, and yet the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: economic and political system which he sought to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: create might be just as desirable as his followers
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: suppose. Syndicalism, however, criticises, not only
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Marx's views of fact, but also the goal at which he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: aims and the general nature of the means which he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: recommends. Marx's ideas were formed at a time
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when democracy did not yet exist. It was in the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: very year in which ``Das Kapital'' appeared that
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: urban working men first got the vote in England and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: universal suffrage was granted by Bismarck in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Northern Germany. It was natural that great hopes
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: should be entertained as to what democracy would
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: achieve. Marx, like the orthodox economists,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: imagined that men's opinions are guided by a more
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or less enlightened view of economic self-interest, or
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rather of economic class interest. A long experience
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the workings of political democracy has shown
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that in this respect Disraeli and Bismarck were
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: shrewder judges of human nature than either Liberals
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or Socialists. It has become increasingly difficult
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to put trust in the State as a means to liberty,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or in political parties as instruments sufficiently
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: powerful to force the State into the service of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: people. The modern State, says Sorel, ``is a body of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: intellectuals, which is invested with privileges, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which possesses means of the kind called political for
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: defending itself against the attacks made on it by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other groups of intellectuals, eager to possess the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: profits of public employment. Parties are constituted
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in order to acquire the conquest of these
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: employments, and they are analogous to the State.''[10]
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [10] La Decomposition du Marxisme,'' p. 53.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Syndicalists aim at organizing men, not by party,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but by occupation. This, they say, alone represents
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the true conception and method of the class war.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Accordingly they despise all POLITICAL action through
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the medium of Parliament and elections: the kind of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: action that they recommend is direct action by the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: revolutionary syndicate or trade union. The battle-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cry of industrial versus political action has spread
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: far beyond the ranks of French Syndicalism. It is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be found in the I. W. W. in America, and among
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Industrial Unionists and Guild Socialists in Great
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Britain. Those who advocate it, for the most part,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: aim also at a different goal from that of Marx. They
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believe that there can be no adequate individual
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: freedom where the State is all-powerful, even if the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: State be a Socialist one. Some of them are out-and-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: out Anarchists, who wish to see the State wholly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: abolished; others only wish to curtail its authority.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Owing to this movement, opposition to Marx, which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from the Anarchist side existed from the first, has
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER II
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: BAKUNIN AND ANARCHISM
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: IN the popular mind, an Anarchist is a person
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who throws bombs and commits other outrages,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: either because he is more or less insane, or because
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he uses the pretense of extreme political opinions as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a cloak for criminal proclivities. This view is, of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: course, in every way inadequate. Some Anarchists
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: believe in throwing bombs; many do not. Men of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: almost every other shade of opinion believe in throwing
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bombs in suitable circumstances: for example,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the men who threw the bomb at Sarajevo which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: started the present war were not Anarchists, but
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Nationalists. And those Anarchists who are in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: favor of bomb-throwing do not in this respect differ
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on any vital principle from the rest of the community,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with the exception of that infinitesimal portion
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who adopt the Tolstoyan attitude of non-resistance.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchists, like Socialists, usually believe
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the doctrine of the class war, and if they use
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bombs, it is as Governments use bombs, for purposes
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of war: but for every bomb manufactured by an
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchist, many millions are manufactured by Governments,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and for every man killed by Anarchist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: violence, many millions are killed by the violence of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: States. We may, therefore, dismiss from our minds
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the whole question of violence, which plays so large
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a part in the popular imagination, since it is neither
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: essential nor peculiar to those who adopt the Anarchist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: position.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchism, as its derivation indicates, is the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: theory which is opposed to every kind of forcible
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: government. It is opposed to the State as the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: embodiment of the force employed in the government
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the community. Such government as Anarchism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can tolerate must be free government, not merely in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the sense that it is that of a majority, but in the sense
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it is that assented to by all. Anarchists object
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to such institutions as the police and the criminal
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: law, by means of which the will of one part of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: community is forced upon another part. In their
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: view, the democratic form of government is not very
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enormously preferable to other forms so long as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minorities are compelled by force or its potentiality
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to submit to the will of majorities. Liberty is the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: supreme good in the Anarchist creed, and liberty
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is sought by the direct road of abolishing all forcible
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: control over the individual by the community.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchism, in this sense, is no new doctrine. It
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is set forth admirably by Chuang Tzu, a Chinese philosopher,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who lived about the year 300 B. C.:--
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Horses have hoofs to carry them over frost and snow;
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hair, to protect them from wind and cold. They eat grass
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and drink water, and fling up their heels over the champaign.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Such is the real nature of horses. Palatial
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dwellings are of no use to them.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: One day Po Lo appeared, saying: ``I understand the

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: management of horses.''
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: So he branded them, and clipped them, and pared
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: their hoofs, and put halters on them, tying them up by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the head and shackling them by the feet, and disposing
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them in stables, with the result that two or three in

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

text: that in that case the State might merely inherit the

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

text: mainly within the Socialist movement as its extreme
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

text: Michel Bakunin was born in 1814 of a Russian

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: man as when he entered.''[14]
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [14] Ibid. p. xxvi.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: After the death of the Tsar Nicholas many political
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: prisoners were amnested, but Alexander II with
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his own hand erased Bakunin's name from the list.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: When Bakunin's mother succeeded in obtaining an
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: interview with the new Tsar, he said to her, ``Know,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Madame, that so long as your son lives, he can never
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be free.'' However, in 1857, after eight years of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: captivity, he was sent to the comparative freedom of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Siberia. From there, in 1861, he succeeded in escaping
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to Japan, and thence through America to London.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: He had been imprisoned for his hostility to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: governments, but, strange to say, his sufferings had
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not had the intended effect of making him love those
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who inflicted them. From this time onward, he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: devoted himself to spreading the spirit of Anarchist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: revolt, without, however, having to suffer any further
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: term of imprisonment. For some years he lived in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Italy, where he founded in 1864 an ``International
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Fraternity'' or ``Alliance of Socialist Revolutionaries.''
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This contained men of many countries, but
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: apparently no Germans. It devoted itself largely to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: combating Mazzini's nationalism. In 1867 he moved
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to Switzerland, where in the following year he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: helped to found the ``International Alliance of So-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cialist Democracy,'' of which he drew up the program.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This program gives a good succinct resume of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his opinions:--
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The Alliance declares itself atheist; it desires the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: definitive and entire abolition of classes and the political
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: equality and social equalization of individuals of both
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sexes. It desires that the earth, the instrument of labor,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: like all other capital, becoming the collective property of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: society as a whole, shall be no longer able to be utilized
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: except by the workers, that is to say, by agricultural and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: industrial associations. It recognizes that all actually
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existing political and authoritarian States, reducing
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: themselves more and more to the mere administrative functions
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the public services in their respective countries,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must disappear in the universal union of free
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: associations, both agricultural and industrial.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The International Alliance of Socialist Democracy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: desired to become a branch of the International
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Working Men's Association, but was refused admission
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on the ground that branches must be local, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: could not themselves be international. The Geneva
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: group of the Alliance, however, was admitted later,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in July, 1869.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The International Working Men's Association
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: had been founded in London in 1864, and its statutes
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and program were drawn up by Marx. Bakunin at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: first did not expect it to prove a success and refused
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to join it. But it spread with remarkable rapidity
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in many countries and soon became a great power
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for the propagation of Socialist ideas. Originally
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it was by no means wholly Socialist, but in successive
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Congresses Marx won it over more and more to his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: views. At its third Congress, in Brussels in September,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 1868, it became definitely Socialist. Meanwhile
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Bakunin, regretting his earlier abstention, had
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: decided to join it, and he brought with him a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: considerable following in French-Switzerland, France,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Spain and Italy. At the fourth Congress, held at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Basle in September, 1869, two currents were strongly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: marked. The Germans and English followed Marx
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in his belief in the State as it was to become after the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: abolition of private property; they followed him also
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in his desire to found Labor Parties in the various
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: countries, and to utilize the machinery of democracy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for the election of representatives of Labor to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Parliaments. On the other hand, the Latin nations in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the main followed Bakunin in opposing the State and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: disbelieving in the machinery of representative
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: government. The conflict between these two groups grew
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: more and more bitter, and each accused the other
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of various offenses. The statement that Bakunin
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was a spy was repeated, but was withdrawn after
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: investigation. Marx wrote in a confidential
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: communication to his German friends that Bakunin was
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an agent of the Pan-Slavist party and received from
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them 25,000 francs a year. Meanwhile, Bakunin
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: became for a time interested in the attempt to stir
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: up an agrarian revolt in Russia, and this led him
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to neglect the contest in the International at a crucial
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: moment. During the Franco-Prussian war Bakunin
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: passionately took the side of France, especially after
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the fall of Napoleon III. He endeavored to rouse
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the people to revolutionary resistance like that of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 1793, and became involved in an abortive attempt at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: revolt in Lyons. The French Government accused
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: him of being a paid agent of Prussia, and it was
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with difficulty that he escaped to Switzerland. The
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dispute with Marx and his followers had become
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exacerbated by the national dispute. Bakunin, like
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Kropotkin after him, regarded the new power of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Germany as the greatest menace to liberty in the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world. He hated the Germans with a bitter hatred,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: partly, no doubt, on account of Bismarck, but probably
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: still more on account of Marx. To this day,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchism has remained confined almost exclusively
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the Latin countries, and has been associated with, a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hatred of Germany, growing out of the contests
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: between Marx and Bakunin in the International.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The final suppression of Bakunin's faction
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: occurred at the General Congress of the International
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at the Hague in 1872. The meeting-place was
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chosen by the General Council (in which Marx was
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unopposed), with a view--so Bakunin's friends contend--
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to making access impossible for Bakunin (on
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: account of the hostility of the French and German
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: governments) and difficult for his friends. Bakunin
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was expelled from the International as the result of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a report accusing him inter alia of theft backed; up
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by intimidation.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The orthodoxy of the International was saved,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but at the cost of its vitality. From this time onward,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it ceased to be itself a power, but both sections continued
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to work in their various groups, and the Socialist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: groups in particular grew rapidly. Ultimately
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a new International was formed (1889) which continued
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: down to the outbreak of the present war. As
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the future of International Socialism it would be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rash to prophesy, though it would seem that the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: international idea has acquired sufficient strength to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: need again, after the war, some such means of expression
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as it found before in Socialist congresses.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: By this time Bakunin's health was broken, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: except for a few brief intervals, he lived in retirement
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: until his death in 1876.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Bakunin's life, unlike Marx's, was a very stormy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one. Every kind of rebellion against authority
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: always aroused his sympathy, and in his support he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: never paid the slightest attention to personal risk.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: His influence, undoubtedly very great, arose chiefly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: through the influence of his personality upon important
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: individuals. His writings differ from Marx's as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: much as his life does, and in a similar way. They are
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: chaotic, largely, aroused by some passing occasion,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: abstract and metaphysical, except when they deal
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with current politics. He does not come to close
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: quarters with economic facts, but dwells usually in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the regions of theory and metaphysics. When he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: descends from these regions, he is much more at the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: mercy of current international politics than Marx,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: much less imbued with the consequences of the belief
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it is economic causes that are fundamental. He
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: praised Marx for enunciating this doctrine,[15] but
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: nevertheless continued to think in terms of nations.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: His longest work, ``L'Empire Knouto-Germanique et
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: la Revolution Sociale,'' is mainly concerned with the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: situation in France during the later stages of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Franco-Prussian War, and with the means of resisting
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: German imperialism. Most of his writing was
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: done in a hurry in the interval between two insurrections.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There is something of Anarchism in his lack
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of literary order. His best-known work is a fragment
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: entitled by its editors ``God and the State.''[16]
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In this work he represents belief in God and belief in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the State as the two great obstacles to human liberty.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: A typical passage will serve to illustrate its style.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [15] ``Marx, as a thinker, is on the right road. He has established
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as a principle that all the evolutions, political, religious,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and juridical, in history are, not the causes, but the effects of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: economic evolutions. This is a great and fruitful thought, which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he has not absolutely invented; it has been glimpsed, expressed
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in part, by many others besides him; but in any case to him
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: belongs the honor of having solidly established it and of having
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enunciated it as the basis of his whole economic system. (1870;
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ib. ii. p. xiii.)
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [16] This title is not Bakunin's, but was invented by Cafiero
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and Elisee Reclus, who edited it, not knowing that it was a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fragment of what was intended to he the second version of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ``L'Empire Knouto-Germanique'' (see ib. ii. p 283).
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The State is not society, it is only an historical form
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of it, as brutal as it is abstract. It was born historically
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in all countries of the marriage of violence, rapine, pillage,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in a word, war and conquest, with the gods successively
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: created by the theological fantasy of nations.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It has been from its origin, and it remains still at present,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the divine sanction of brutal force and triumphant
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: inequality.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The State is authority; it is force; it is the ostentation
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and infatuation of force: it does not insinuate
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: itself; it does not seek to convert. . . . Even when
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: it commands what is good, it hinders and spoils it, just
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because it commands it, and because every command provokes
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and excites the legitimate revolts of liberty; and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because the good, from the moment that it is commanded,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: becomes evil from the point of view of true morality, of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: human morality (doubtless not of divine), from the point
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of view of human respect and of liberty. Liberty, morality,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and the human dignity of man consist precisely
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in this, that he does good, not because it is commanded,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but because he conceives it, wills it and loves it.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We do not find in Bakunin's works a clear picture
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the society at which he aimed, or any argument
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to prove that such a society could be stable.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: If we wish to understand Anarchism we must turn
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to his followers, and especially to Kropotkin--like
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: him, a Russian aristocrat familiar with the prisons
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of Europe, and, like him, an Anarchist who, in spite
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of his internationalism, is imbued with a fiery hatred
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the Germans.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Kropotkin has devoted much of his writing to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: technical questions of production. In ``Fields,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Factories and Workshops'' and ``The Conquest of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Bread'' he has set himself to prove that, if production
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were more scientific and better organized, a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: comparatively small amount of quite agreeable work
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would suffice to keep the whole population in comfort.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Even assuming, as we probably must, that he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: somewhat exaggerates what is possible with our
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present scientific knowledge, it must nevertheless be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conceded that his contentions contain a very large
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: measure of truth. In attacking the subject of production
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he has shown that he knows what is the really
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: crucial question. If civilization and progress are to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be compatible with equality, it is necessary that
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: equality should not involve long hours of painful
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: toil for little more than the necessaries of life, since,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: where there is no leisure, art and science will die and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all progress will become impossible. The objection
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which some feel to Socialism and Anarchism alike on
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this ground cannot be upheld in view of the possible
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: productivity of labor.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The system at which Kropotkin aims, whether or
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not it be possible, is certainly one which demands a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: very great improvement in the methods of production
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: above what is common at present. He desires
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to abolish wholly the system of wages, not only, as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: most Socialists do, in the sense that a man is to be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: paid rather for his willingness to work than for the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: actual work demanded of him, but in a more fundamental
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sense: there is to be no obligation to work,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and all things are to be shared in equal proportions
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: among the whole population. Kropotkin relies upon
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the possibility of making work pleasant: he holds
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that, in such a community as he foresees, practically
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: everyone will prefer work to idleness, because work will
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: not involve overwork or slavery, or that excessive
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: specialization that industrialism has brought about,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but will be merely a pleasant activity for certain
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hours of the day, giving a man an outlet for his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spontaneous constructive impulses. There is to be no
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: compulsion, no law, no government exercising force;
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there will still be acts of the community, but these
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are to spring from universal consent, not from any
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: enforced submission of even the smallest minority.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: We shall examine in a later chapter how far such
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an ideal is realizable, but it cannot be denied that

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the population will continue to increase indefinitely,

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and in any case the prospect is so remote that it may

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Returning from these dim speculations to the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: facts set forth by Kropotkin, we find it proved in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his writings that, by methods of intensive cultivation,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which are already in actual operation, the amount of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: food produced on a given area can be increased far
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: beyond anything that most uninformed persons suppose
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible. Speaking of the market-gardeners in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Great Britain, in the neighborhood of Paris, and in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other places, he says:--
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: They have created a totally new agriculture. They
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: smile when we boast about the rotation system having
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: permitted us to take from the field one crop every year,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or four crops each three years, because their ambition is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to have six and nine crops from the very same plot of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: land during the twelve months. They do not understand
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: our talk about good and bad soils, because they make
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the soil themselves, and make it in such quantities as to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be compelled yearly to sell some of it; otherwise it would
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: raise up the level of their gardens by half an inch every
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: year. They aim at cropping, not five or six tons of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: grass on the acre, as we do, but from 50 to 100 tons of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: various vegetables on the same space; not 5 pound sworth of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hay, but 100 pounds worth of vegetables, of the plainest description,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: cabbage and carrots.[38]
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [38] Kropotkin, ``Fields, Factories and Workshops,'' p. 74.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: As regards cattle, he mentions that Mr. Champion
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at Whitby grows on each acre the food of two or
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: three head of cattle, whereas under ordinary high
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: farming it takes two or three acres to keep each head
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of cattle in Great Britain. Even more astonishing
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are the achievements of the Culture Maraicheres
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: round Paris. It is impossible to summarize these
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: achievements, but we may note the general
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conclusion:--
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There are now practical Maraichers who venture to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: maintain that if all the food, animal and vegetable,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: necessary for the 3,500,000 inhabitants of the Departments
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of Seine and Seine-et-Oise had to be grown on
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: their own territory (3250 square miles), it could be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: grown without resorting to any other methods of culture
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than those already in use--methods already tested on a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: large scale and proved successful.[39]
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It must be remembered that these two departments
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: include the whole population of Paris.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Kropotkin proceeds to point out methods by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which the same result could be achieved without long
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hours of labor. Indeed, he contends that the great
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bulk of agricultural work could be carried on by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: people whose main occupations are sedentary, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: with only such a number of hours as would serve to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: keep them in health and produce a pleasant diversification.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: He protests against the theory of exces-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sive division of labor. What he wants is INTEGRATION,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ``a society where each individual is a producer of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: both manual and intellectual work; where each able-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bodied human being is a worker, and where each
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: worker works both in the field and in the industrial
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: workshop.''[40]
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [40] Kropotkin, ``Field, Factories, and Workshops,'' p. 6.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: These views as to production have no essential
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: connection with Kropotkin's advocacy of Anarchism.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: They would be equally possible under State
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socialism, and under certain circumstances they
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: might even be carried out in a capitalistic regime.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: They are important for our present purpose, not
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from any argument which they afford in favor of one
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: economic system as against another, but from the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fact that they remove the veto upon our hopes which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: might otherwise result from a doubt as to the productive
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capacity of labor. I have dwelt upon agriculture
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rather than industry, since it is in regard
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to agriculture that the difficulties are chiefly supposed
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to arise. Broadly speaking, industrial production
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tends to be cheaper when it is carried on on
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a large scale, and therefore there is no reason in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: industry why an increase in the demand should lead
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to an increased cost of supply.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Passing now from the purely technical and material
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: side of the problem of production, we come
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the human factor, the motives leading men to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work, the possibilities of efficient organization of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: production, and the connection of production with
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distribution. Defenders of the existing system
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: maintain that efficient work would be impossible without
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the economic stimulus, and that if the wage
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: system were abolished men would cease to do enough
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work to keep the community in tolerable comfort.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Through the alleged necessity of the economic motive,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the problems of production and distribution
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: become intertwined. The desire for a more just
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: distribution of the world's goods is the main inspiration
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of most Socialism and Anarchism. We must,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: therefore, consider whether the system of distribution
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which they propose would be likely to lead to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a diminished production.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There is a fundamental difference between Socialism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and Anarchism as regards the question of distribution.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socialism, at any rate in most of its
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: forms, would retain payment for work done or for
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: willingness to work, and, except in the case of persons
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: incapacitated by age or infirmity, would make
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: willingness to work a condition of subsistence, or at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: any rate of subsistence above a certain very low
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: minimum. Anarchism, on the other hand, aims at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: granting to everyone, without any conditions whatever,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: just as much of all ordinary commodities as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he or she may care to consume, while the rarer com-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: modities, of which the supply cannot easily be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indefinitely increased, would be rationed and divided
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: equally among the population. Thus Anarchism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would not impose any OBLIGATIONS of work, though
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchists believe that the necessary work could be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: made sufficiently agreeable for the vast majority of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the population to undertake it voluntarily. Socialists,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on the other hand, would exact work. Some of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them would make the incomes of all workers equal,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: while others would retain higher pay for the work
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which is considered more valuable. All these different
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: systems are compatible with the common ownership
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of land and capital, though they differ greatly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as regards the kind of society which they would
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: produce.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socialism with inequality of income would not
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: differ greatly as regards the economic stimulus to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work from the society in which we live. Such differences
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as it would entail would undoubtedly be to the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: good from our present point of view. Under the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: existing system many people enjoy idleness and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: affluence through the mere accident of inheriting land
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or capital. Many others, through their activities in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: industry or finance, enjoy an income which is certainly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: very far in excess of anything to which their
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: social utility entitles them. On the other hand, it
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: often happens that inventors and discoverers, whose
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work has the very greatest social utility, are robbed
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of their reward either by capitalists or by the failure
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the public to appreciate their work until too
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: late. The better paid work is only open to those who
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have been able to afford an expensive training, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: these men are selected in the main not by merit but
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by luck. The wage earner is not paid for his willingness
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to work, but only for his utility to the employer.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Consequently, he may be plunged into destitution by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: causes over which he has no control. Such destitution
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is a constant fear, and when it occurs it produces
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: undeserved suffering, and often deterioration
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the social value of the sufferer. These are a few
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: among the evils of our existing system from the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: standpoint of production. All these evils we might
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: expect to see remedied under any system of Socialism.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There are two questions which need to be considered
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: when we are discussing how far work requires
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand
