title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: society give higher pay for the more skilled or socially
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: more valuable work, if such work is to be done in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sufficient quantities? The second question is: Could
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work be made so attractive that enough of it would
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be done even if idlers received just as much of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: produce of work? The first of these questions concerns
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the division between two schools of Socialists:
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the more moderate Socialists sometimes concede that
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: even under Socialism it would be well to retain
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: unequal pay for different kinds of work, while the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: more thoroughgoing Socialists advocate equal
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: incomes for all workers. The second question, on the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other hand, forms a division between Socialists and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Anarchists; the latter would not deprive a man of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: commodities if he did not work, while the former in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: general would.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Our second question is so much more fundamental
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than our first that it must be discussed at once, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the course of this discussion what needs to be said
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: on our first question will find its place naturally.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Wages or Free Sharing?--``Abolition of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of society all the commoner commodities will

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be available to everyone without stint, in the kind
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of way in which water is available at present.[41] Advo-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: indefinitely more productive--that all the commoner
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: kinds of food could be given away to all who demanded

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: them, since it would be easy to produce them in quantities

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: adequate to any possible demand. If this system

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spend his time. As for commodities which cannot
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be produced in indefinite quantities, such as luxuries
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [44] ``As to the so-often repeated objection that nobody would

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The attitude of orthodox Socialism on this question

text: to labor. Establishment of industrial armies, especially

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in general, work alone gives the right to the enjoyment

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the produce of work. To this theory there

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: CHAPTER V
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: GOVERNMENT AND LAW
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: GOVERNMENT and Law, in their very essence, consist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of restrictions on freedom, and freedom is the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: greatest of political goods.[46] A hasty reasoner might
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: conclude without further ado that Law and government
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are evils which must be abolished if freedom
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is our goal. But this consequence, true or false, cannot
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be proved so simply. In this chapter we shall
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: examine the arguments of Anarchists against law and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the State. We shall proceed on the assumption that
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: freedom is the supreme aim of a good social system;
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but on this very basis we shall find the Anarchist
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: contentions very questionable.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [46] I do not say freedom is the greatest of ALL goods: the best
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: things come from within--they are such things as creative art,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by political conditions, but not actually produced by them; and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: freedom is, both in itself and in its relation to these other goods
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the best thing that political and economic conditions can secure.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Respect for the liberty of others is not a natural
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: impulse with most men: envy and love of power lead
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: were wholly unchecked by external authority, we
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: should not obtain a world in which all men would be

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: free. The strong would oppress the weak, or the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: majority would oppress the minority, or the lovers
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of violence would oppress the more peaceable people.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: I fear it cannot be said that these bad impulses are

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is chiefly promoted as a rule by the actual experience

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of power. In a world where none could acquire

author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the community, may either succeed in establishing

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proletariat during its contest with the bourgeoisie is

text: the creative impulse; third, at least the possibility of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ultimate appreciation by some public, whether large
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: or small. We may leave out of our discussion both
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: individual genius and those intangible conditions
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which make some ages great and others sterile in art
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and science--not because these are unimportant, but
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: because they are too little understood to be taken
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: account of in economic or political organization.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The three conditions we have mentioned seem to cover
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: most of what can be SEEN to be useful or harmful
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from our present point of view, and it is therefore
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to them that we shall confine ourselves.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 1. Technical Training.--Technical training at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present, whether in science or art, requires one or
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: other of two conditions. Either a boy must be the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: son of well-to-do parents who can afford to keep
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: him while he acquires his education, or he must show
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: so much ability at an early age as to enable him to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: subsist on scholarships until he is ready to earn his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: living. The former condition is, of course, a mere
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: matter of luck, and could not be preserved in its
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present form under any kind of Socialism or Communism.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: This loss is emphasized by defenders of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present system, and no doubt it would be, to same
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: extent, a real loss. But the well-to-do are a small
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proportion of the population, and presumably on the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: average no more talented by nature than their less
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: fortunate contemporaries. If the advantages which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are enjoyed now by those few among them who are
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capable of good work in science or art could be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: extended, even in a slightly attenuated form, to all
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who are similarly gifted, the result would almost
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: infallibly be a gain, and much ability which is now
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wasted would be rendered fruitful. But how is this
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to be effected?
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The system of scholarships obtained by competition,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: though better than nothing, is objectionable
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: from many points of view. It introduces the competitive
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: spirit into the work of the very young; it
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: makes them regard knowledge from the standpoint
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of what is useful in examinations rather than in the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: light of its intrinsic interest or importance; it places
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a premium upon that sort of ability which is displayed
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: precociously in glib answers to set questions
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: rather than upon the kind that broods on difficulties
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and remains for a time rather dumb. What is perhaps
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: worse than any of these defects is the tendency
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to cause overwork in youth, leading to lack of vigor
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and interest when manhood has been reached. It
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: can hardly be doubted that by this cause, at present,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: many fine minds have their edge blunted and their
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: keenness destroyed.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: State Socialism might easily universalize the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: system of scholarships obtained by competitive examination,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and if it did so it is to he feared that it
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would be very harmful. State Socialists at present
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: tend to be enamored of the systems which is exactly
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the kind that every bureaucrat loves: orderly,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: neat, giving a stimulus to industrious habits, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: involving no waste of a sort that could be tabulated
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in statistics or accounts of public expenditure.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Such men will argue that free higher education is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: expensive to the community, and only useful in the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: case of those who have exceptional abilities; it
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: ought, therefore, they will say, not to be given to all,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but only to those who will become more useful members
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of society through receiving it. Such arguments
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: make a great appeal to what are called ``practical''
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: men, and the answers to them are of a sort which it
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is difficult to render widely convincing. Revolt
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: against the evils of competition is, however, part
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the very essence of the Socialist's protest against
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the existing order, and on this ground, if on no other,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: those who favor Socialism may be summoned to look
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for some better solution.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Much the simplest solution, and the only really
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: effective one, is to make every kind of education free
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: up to the age of twenty-one for all boys and girls
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who desire it. The majority will be tired of education
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: before that age, and will prefer to begin other
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work sooner; this will lead to a natural selection of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: those with strong interests in some pursuit requiring
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a long training. Among those selected in this way
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by their own inclinations, probably almost all tho
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: have marked abilities of the kind in question will be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: included. It is true that there will also be many
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who have very little ability; the desire to become a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: painter, for example, is by no means confined to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: those who can paint. But this degree of waste could
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: well be borne by the community; it would be immeasurably
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: less than that now entailed by the support
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of the idle rich. Any system which aims at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: avoiding this kind of waste must entail the far more
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: serious waste of rejecting or spoiling some of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: best ability in each generation. The system of free
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: education up to any grade for all who desire it is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the only system which is consistent with the principles
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of liberty, and the only one which gives a reasonable
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hope of affording full scope for talent. This system
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is equally compatible with all forms of Socialism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and Anarchism. Theoretically, it is compatible with
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: capitalism, but practically it is so opposite in spirit
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: that it would hardly be feasible without a complete
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: economic reconstruction. The fact that Socialism
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would facilitate it must be reckoned a very powerful
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: argument in favor of change, for the waste of talent
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: at present in the poorer classes of society must be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: stupendous.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: 2. Liberty to follow the creative impulse.--
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: When a man's training has been completed, if he is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possessed of really great abilities, he will do his best
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: work if he is completely free to follow his bent,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: creating what seems good to him, regardless of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: judgment of ``experts.'' At present this is only
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: possible for two classes of people: those who have
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: private means, and those who can earn a living by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an occupation that does not absorb their whole
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: energies. Under Socialism, there will be no one with
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: private means, and if there is to be no loss as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regards art and science, the opportunity which now
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: comes by accident to a few will have to be provided
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: deliberately for a much larger number. The men
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who have used private means as an opportunity for
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: creative work have been few but important: one
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: might mention Milton, Shelley, Keats and Darwin as
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: examples. Probably none of these would have produced
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as good work if they had had to earn their
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: livelihood. If Darwin had been a university teacher,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: he would of course have been dismissed from his post
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: by the influence of the clerics on account of his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: scandalous theories.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Nevertheless, the bulk of the creative work of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world is done at present by men who subsist by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some other occupation. Science, and research generally,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: are usually done in their spare time by men
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: who live by teaching. There is no great objection to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: this in the case of science, provided the number of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: hours devoted to teaching is not excessive. It is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: partly because science and teaching are so easily
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: combined that science is vigorous in the present age.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In music, a composer who is also a performer enjoys
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: similar advantages, but one who is not a performer
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must starve, unless he is rich or willing to pander to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the public taste. In the fine arts, as a rule, it is not
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: easy in the modern world either to make a living by
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: really good work or to find a subsidiary profession
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: which leaves enough leisure for creation. This is
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: presumably one reason, though by no means the only
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: one, why art is less flourishing than science.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The bureaucratic State Socialist will have a
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: simple solution for these difficulties. He will appoint
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a body consisting of the most eminent celebrities in
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: an art or a science, whose business it shall be to judge
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the work of young men, and to issue licenses to those
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: whose productions find favor in their eyes. A licensed
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: artist shall be considered to have performed his duty
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to the community by producing works of art. But of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: course he will have to prove his industry by never
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: failing to produce in reasonable quantities, and his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: continued ability by never failing to please his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: eminent judges--until, in the fulness of time, he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: becomes a judge himself. In this way, the authorities
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will insure that the artist shall be competent,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: regular, and obedient to the best traditions of his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: art. Those who fail to fulfil these conditions will be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: compelled by the withdrawal of their license to seek
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some less dubious mode of earning their living. Such
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: will be the ideal of the State Socialist.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: In such a world all that makes life tolerable to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the lover of beauty would perish. Art springs from
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a wild and anarchic side of human nature; between
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the artist and the bureaucrat there must always be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a profound mutual antagonism, an age-long battle
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in which the artist, always outwardly worsted, wins
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: in the end through the gratitude of mankind for the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: joy that he puts into their lives. If the wild side
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of human nature is to be permanently subjected to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: the orderly rules of the benevolent, uncomprehending
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: bureaucrat, the joy of life will perish out of the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: earth, and the very impulse to live will gradually
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wither and die. Better a thousandfold the present
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: world with all its horrors than such a dead mummy
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of a world. Better Anarchism, with all its risks,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than a State Socialism that subjects to rule what
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: must be spontaneous and free if it is to have any
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: value. It is this nightmare that makes artists, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: lovers of beauty generally, so often suspicious of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socialism. But there is nothing in the essence of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Socialism to make art impossible: only certain forms
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of Socialism would entail this danger. William
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Morris was a Socialist, and was a Socialist very
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: largely because he was an artist. And in this he
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was not irrational.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: It is impossible for art, or any of the higher
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: creative activities, to flourish under any system which
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: requires that the artist shall prove his competence to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some body of authorities before he is allowed to follow
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: his impulse. Any really great artist is almost
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sure to be thought incompetent by those among his
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: seniors who would be generally regarded as best
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: qualified to form an opinion. And the mere fact of
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: having to produce work which will please older men
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: is hostile to a free spirit and to bold innovation.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Apart from this difficulty, selection by older men
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: would lead to jealousy and intrigue and back-biting,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: producing a poisonous atmosphere of underground
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: competition. The only effect of such a plan would be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to eliminate the few who now slip through owing to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: some fortunate accident. It is not by any system,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but by freedom alone, that art can flourish.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: There are two ways by which the artist could
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: secure freedom under Socialism of the right kind.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: He might undertake regular work outside his art,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: doing only a few hours' work a day and receiving
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: proportionately less pay than those who do a full
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: day's work. He ought, in that case, to be at liberty
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to sell his pictures if he could find purchasers. Such
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: a system would have many advantages. It would
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: leave absolutely every man free to become an artist,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: provided he were willing to suffer a certain economic
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: loss. This would not deter those in whom the impulse
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: was strong and genuine, but would tend to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: exclude the dilettante. Many young artists at
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: present endure voluntarily much greater poverty
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: than need be entailed by only doing half the usual
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: day's work in a well-organized Socialist community;
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and some degree of hardship is not objectionable,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as a test of the strength of the creative impulse, and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: as an offset to the peculiar joys of the creative life.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The other possibility[58] would be that the necessaries
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: of life should be free, as Anarchists desire, to
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: all equally, regardless of whether they work or not.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: Under this plan, every man could live without work:
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: there would be what might be called a ``vagabond's
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wage,'' sufficient for existence but not for luxury.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: The artist who preferred to have his whole time for
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: art and enjoyment might live on the ``vagabond's
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: wage''--traveling on foot when the humor seized him
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to see foreign countries, enjoying the air and the
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: sun, as free as the birds, and perhaps scarcely less
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: happy. Such men would bring color and diversity
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: into the life of the community; their outlook would be
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: different from that of steady, stay-at-home workers,
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: and would keep alive a much-needed element of light-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: heartedness which our sober, serious civilization tends
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: to kill. If they became very numerous, they might
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: be too great an economic burden on the workers;
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: but I doubt if there are many with enough capacity
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: for simple enjoyments to choose poverty and free-
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: dom in preference to the comparatively light and
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: pleasant work which will be usual in those days.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: [58] Which we discussed in Chapter IV.
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: By either of these methods, freedom can be preserved

text: 3. Possibility of Appreciation.--This condition
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
author: Russell, Bertrand

text: IN the daily lives of most men and women, fear
title: Proposed Roads to Freedom

title: Proposed Roads to Freedom
